review_title: I would love to give more stars but...
pros:
-Making a difference for those who live in your community
-Being a Transporter you are everywhere so you see a lot and are able to pick up a lot of medical knowledge
-Most of the employee's work together as a team
-You can start in the kitchen but their is absolutely room to grow and find a career that will benefit you for life.
-Company does preach great value's
cons:
-The select few employee's that don't want to work together help get those who are essential to making sure things are run smoothly fired.
-The more demanding your job is the less you are recognized and other department's see that so they look down on you. Then you are treated and spoken to negatively.
-The pay DID NOT equal the amount of work you did. Now the minimum is $18 which is definitely better but while I was there it seemed unfair.
-If pay is raised employee's who have been there longer and have seen their pay raise over time should not be equal to those that just received their $18. What ever raises they have received over the last 10 years should be matched. They did not work hard all this time just to now be equal.
-The more I treated patient's as an individual instead of a number the unhappier higher ups were. They want you to move as fast as possible to make money off of the testing you bring your patient's to.
-The value's they preach are ignored the higher up you go. You can walk into work everyday with the best of intention's but be broken hearted by the end of the day due to other's not practicing what they preach.

pros: Not all share the same culture, each institution has its own in AHS.  So if you don't feel good in one, try another before resigning.  The old family culture was better, now is becoming more institutionalized.  As the seniors retire or fired, the new blood brings their own compelling judgement.  Good benefits in-network.
cons: The perception is that money is tight, but they keep purchasing hospitals... yet at some departments supplies are misused, no motivation to use wisely the resources, including the gossip time, down time and  wasted time.  Someone who attended a board meeting mentioned that an strategy to lower the budget was to fired more senior employees, sure this will eventually come back to them, generation x will not hold loyalty to the institution more than to themselves, I expect turnover to gain momentum, good for young but sad and a sacrilege to those who served, give and would keep on giving until they can and more.

review_title: Good benefits and place to work, but long hiring process
pros:
Great overall company to work for. Benefits are amazing if you live in the area you work in. The Different hospitals and offices are very different work places. I work at Newton Medical Center and believe it's a healthy happy place to work. Although NMC is like the ugly step sister of Morristown hospital. 

The different shifts make it easy to have a life outside of work.
cons: Employees can be very two faced or catty to each other. Most ER staff seem miserable in their positions but other departments don't seem that way. Different departments don't respect one another, specifically employees in patient care (nurses, techs, Dr's) don't really respect or treat someone in billing, admissions, patient access nicely or with respect. Corporate also doesn't seem to understand to going one from one facility to another and expects everyone to be like Morristown.

pros: Great PTO package, offer 5k a year in tuition reimbursement, and various discounts to employees
cons: The change in covered health benefits is terrible. So many disgruntled employees over this including myself.. when employees become upset it is reflected in their patient care. I have SO many issues with HR as do my coworkers and the department is atrocious. Nobody answers the phone or returns calls/emails. They throw everything under the rug. Not sure what happened this used to be a great place to work and HR had your back. Now it’s nothing but a fight just to get what you were promised in terms of pay and benefits.

review_title: Crushing employees with work and extra tasks
pros: Good benefits, tuition reimbursement up to $5k/year, good working hours
cons: Only 18 days of PTO/year,  disorganized management, no option to work from home, often people in one department don't know what another department does. People are constantly changing positions, but no one notifies us they've left. It's chaotic. Bravo Wellness is too cumbersome - To get the same insurance discount as last year we had to take two online classes for 12 weeks, do two 4 week challenges, have a physical, and improve from last year's physical. We're all stressed to the max, is anyone surprised our collective blood pressure is high?

review_title: They treat employees of acquired hospitals like something on the bottom of their shoe.
pros: They have a lot of resources and money to throw at problems.  The highest senior management (C-level and some directors) truly seem to care about both the organization and the staff.
cons: Unfortunately the caring attitude of the C-level management does not flow down to the staff.  Their corporate structure is clunky at best, and they need to consider vetting some of their long-term employees before giving them promotions.  It is obvious some people have been in the organization for too long and have no idea what the real world is like.

review_title: Changes are happening and not good ones
pros: There are still great people at Atlantic Health System to work with and still a lot of innovation is taking place. It is better run than most healthcare outfits, and in the list of the fortune 100 best places to work.
cons: New management has taken over and they are making many changes very quickly. They seem old school and favor budget cuts, at a time where investing in the future is the mainstream direction. Controlling cost is important, but in this case the cuts will impact production capability. Employee morale seems to be trending downwards.

review_title: I would not take this job again
job_title: Director of A Service Line Sub-department in Morristown, NJ
pros: Stable seeming system with very little oversight of day to day duties and seemingly no effort or ability by senior managment to ascertain how/what employees are doing or how things are being accomplished.  So - if one is moderately productive and looks good/acts friendly, then it is a stable job for little true hands on knowledge of how to accomplish the job.
cons: The priorities and understanding of the senior management to recognize talent and growth potential in a direction or in an employee is startingly bad.  It's difficult to uncover the reasoning process behind direction changes or timing.  There seems to be a lot of opacity and unrest.

pros: Atlantic Health Systems has great benefits.
cons: My department, the pharmacy, was terrible to work for. Top management did not listen to any complaints or ideas for improvement in the pharmacy at all. The lead technicians are very lazy and have nasty attitudes yet get away with it all. They bring the moral of the department very low. It sucks the life out of you. When all of this is told to the higher management, it was ignored. A lot of great beteran technicians have left because of how miserable to leads make the work environment.

review_title: Company makes new employees pay for parking??
pros: People are mostly nice, genuine.
cons: When you go in to employee health for your physical (which is mandatory for new employees) they tell you to park in visitors parking and then make you pay for parking.... this says a lot about the company. When you’re a working employee you get free parking, but as a new employee it’s not validated?? And you have to pay twice because you need to go back to employee health to get your TB test read. They claim to give a “discount”, which is $1 off, but if you’re paying credit card then the discount does not apply. This alone made me reconsider working here.

review_title: Great Place to work that values employees
pros: This company has grown incredible over the years to become a household brand. They are very careful to grow their brand while keeping their eye on the competition. I found them to be very responsible keeping the salaries competitive and benefits that helped the employees succeed. They held employee appreciation events to celebrate your anniversary (5, 10, 15, etc. years of service) there a true feeling of appreciation and celebration!
cons: some of the departments were cut and outsourced with little or no notice. Some of these had pretty severe consequences. You get the feeling that the managers are looking for ways to cut costs.

pros:
High performing health care system, financially sound, high quality practices.
Benefits and compensation are competitive.
cons: The mission and vision of AHS are aspirational and excellent.  As another reviewer noted, however, the execution of that vision varies radically from department to department, depending on the leadership.  Management is frequently unsupportive, highly critical, micromanaging or else providing no oversight at all.  Employees in these poorly led departments are disillusioned, disempowered, and no longer believe in the mission and vision.

review_title: Pretty satisfied. Many very kind, helpful people--pleasant atmosphere. Some units are exceptional--some are disorganized
pros: Clinical managers in all units are fantastic--so supportive and proactive in managing their units. Continuing education allows for possible advancement.
cons: One of the very few large employers in the area so much competition for jobs. Very hard to obtain a full-time position for any job (including nurses). Part time is now the norm here which makes all the benefits for (only) full-time employees meaningless to most because they do not apply to just part-timers even if you are trying to work as many hours as you can get.

pros: Large company with what seems to be room for growth and improvement. Good benefits and PTO. Classes offered to employees.
cons: There's is no support from upper management. Coordinators are left high and dry with a "figure it out" mentality. There is no proper training to help the coordinators succeed in their positions. Management expects you to work overtime when you are on salary instead of allowing employees, that are hourly, take advantage of the overtime. When you express your frustrations, your concerns are dismissed and personal grudges are held against you. Not only that, but when the concern becomes a global problem management blames the coordinator for the issue.

pros: AHS is a nice place to work. There are good benefits and the work-life balance is really family friendly. They are flexible with telecommuting which is a big plus.
cons: There is a disconnect in terms of moving up an being promoted. I feel like they take advantage of employees and don't pay very well. It is very hard to get a raise.

review_title: Love the Doctors and coworkers..... terrible nurse management
pros: The physicians are mostly lovely. Its a teaching hospital and there are learning opportunities. The people you work with are helpful and make the environment pleasant for the most part.
cons: nurse management is not supportive of nurses  they are slow to praise and quick to criticize. You will almost never get recognition for the work you do. If you do have problems HR is useless. There is no recourse. Also, the pay is not the greatest for the area. most of the nurses I know all had a second job.

pros: Decent benefits, very good work life balance
cons: No room career growth. Very flat organizational chart. Your responsibilities significantly  increase/changes but not your position and definitely not your salary. They prefer to hire somebody from outside for senior leadership positions even if they have someone in-house who is more qualified.

pros: Good coworkers, nice hospital and area (Summit).
cons:
Lower compensation compared to others in area.
403B with only 1%, yup I said 1%!!! Matching.  Industry standard is at least 3%, and this is a top 100 hospital to work for?
-Corporate care model = Staff Less, Pay Less, Do more work!.  It hurts patient care, disrespects its staff and swindles millions of dollars from insurance companies.  But hey! Its all the staff’s fault because we are not working hard enough!.

review_title: If you're ready to coast, this is the place

cons: Politics, the incompetence of many of your co-workers (this company can't seem to find/hang on to smart, talented employees) the total lack of leadership at the senior level.  You are valued not for what you contribute or the results you get, but how well-liked you are.

cons: No execution culture to get to that vision. Wasteful spending especially in IS area. IS has a bully style of management; IS employee morale is down; staff with good reviews and are being let go without justification; the area is demotivating and has no direction. Good talent is leaving.

pros: Thoughtful HR, every voice truly counts, atmosphere where innovation is welcomed and patient care is top priority, good benefits.

pros: Nice people, free coffee, free parking
cons:

pros: Salary is competitive.  Cash-balance pension plan for all full time employees, which is unheard of at most companies.  Health insurance is outstanding.  Paid time off (vacation + sick days + personal days) is very generous.  In-house day care.  Benefits are great.
cons: As other reviewers have mentioned, very politically charged atmosphere.  Bully management isn't unheard of, and favoritism is rampant.  20% work hard, while the other 80% coast toward retirement.  Overspending is a real problem.

pros: Some of the nicest and most dedicated people I have ever met. People whobwork here have a real sense of purpose. Incredible respect at all levels and throughout all of the different locations. Competitive salary, great benefits.

pros: Decent Pay,  Good Health Benefits

review_title: Central Access Overlook Medical Center Managed by bullies!
pros: Atlantic health has great benefits and the saalary is fair.
cons:
I am employed at Central Access/patient access at the Overlook Medical Center. This department is plagued with poor leadership. There is a lot of unprofessionalism in the way matters are handled. Employees aren't spoken to directly if there is an issue. Instead they are gossipped about behind their backs and to other employees and these hunches are used to reprimand staff and bully us into silence. No evidence is needed to be reprimanded. If you are accused of doing something by anyone in leadership, it is taken as the truth and you are ultimately reprimanded for it. Unfair abuse of power. Employees are also encouraged to eavesdrop on each other and bring information to the leaders of the department to get each other written up and fired. Very divisive and juvenile behavior.

Emails have been sent in the past saying employees were not to smile/laugh with other staff members and not allowed to talk on  the job. This among other ridiculous attempts to keep employees from speaking up against the abuse of power and compliance violations that occur in the department. Speaking out is usually met with threats of firing. Atlantic Health System is allowing this to happen. NO ONE should be allowed to affect an employee's performance appraisal, write up, threaten or fire an employee based on unsubstantiated claims. Performance appraisals should be strictly about the job and one's ability to function effectively in the work environment. I cannot believe that I have been out of high school almost 20 years and it feels like im back dealing with mean girls and bullies.

In a nutshell, the turnover that exists in the department is not because people are finding better opportunities. They are in fact fleeing from bullies. They are running away from unprofessionalism, intimidation, threats of firings and their characters being tarnished if they stand up against abuse of power.

Central Access at the Overlook medical center needs to be investigated by the administration. This has been happening for a while with different employees but so many people have been bullied into silence and good staff members have resigned to avoid the petty environment so the problem persists. The department was never like this. It has truly changed as of late.

pros: Workers doing patient care work hard and are wonderful
cons: Management just doesn't get it.  They run you dry.  Everyone is complaining but no one is listening.  Over worked and they nickle and dime you for everything.  It is truly horrible.  I am looking to get out.
